title: Harvesting and Storing Water for Crop Irrigation

tasks.task: Water harvesting and storage for irrigation
subtasks: Collaborating with local agricultural extension systems
Assessing water strain demands during drought periods
Utilizing natural water sources like Limestone Creek
Constructing reservoirs for water storage (140 acre feet capacity)
Pumping water into reservoir during high water flow periods (November to March)
Reusing stored water for irrigation during growing season (dry times)
Considering applications for small-scale farming and specialty crops
Exploring potential uses by municipalities for backup water supplies

The transcript is about water harvesting for irrigation, so the main task should be that. People would need to collaborate with agricultural extension systems (SUBTASK). They have to assess water demands during droughts (SUBTASK) and use natural sources like a creek (SUBTASK). A reservoir is constructed to store 140 acre feet (SUBTASK), and they pump water into it when the creek is full (SUBTASK). Then use that stored water for crops when it's needed (SUBTASK). Also mentioned that this could benefit small farmers and towns (SUBTASK). All these involve physical tasks related to setting up and maintaining irrigation systems, so they should be included as subtasks under the main task of water harvesting for irrigation.
